awd_titl_txt: REU SITE: Research in Consumer Networking Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
This funding renews a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Site at the University of Missouri – Columbia. Undergraduate students will investigate a variety of interesting and challenging problems that involve consumer networking applications and services that are of significance to the economy and quality of life in areas such as social computing, health care, and public safety. The students will participate in the faculty mentors’ on-going funded research, investigate technically challenging issues, and develop viable solutions and insights. They will participate in professional development activities to prepare them for future graduate studies and a broad range of emerging computing careers.  The site will focus on recruiting students from non-PhD granting institutions with particular emphasis on institutions in and around the state of Missouri. 
 
The intellectual merit of the project rests with the leadership, an experienced research group with excellent expertise and experience in the research area. The research will focus on application areas such as public safety, health, nature conservation, and immersive learning   The research activities will lead to a better understanding of the multitude of efficiency, performance, reliability, scalability, and security issues and tradeoffs in consumer networking technologies and related applications. Advanced networking environments and software developed in the previous REU site programs as well as novel testbeds such as the Missouri University Science DMZ (demilitarized zone) environment, NSF-supported CloudLab/GENI (Global Environment for Network Innovation), smart device equipment, and sensor-based monitoring will be leveraged by the participating students in hands-on experiments within their research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
The REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Site at the University of Missouri was in the field of Consumer Networking Technologies and investigates important issues related to software defined networking, visual computing at the network edge, social health networking for eldercare, body-area sensing and emotion recognition. 33 REU students were selected from 289 applications received over the 3-year project period. The REU students worked in world-class collaborative research environments that fostered their enthusiasm for science and engineering, and helped them to develop research and communication skills needed for pursuing advanced degrees. The REU students participated in two field trips, one offered the opportunity to visit and speak with students in grades 6-­8 in the Columbia Public School district’s EEE summer school program; the other was a visit to the University of Missouri’s Data Center. At the end of the program, several students expressed their desire to pursue graduate study. Several graduate assistants were provided the opportunity to mentor undergraduate researchers, which will also significantly benefit their career development. REU students have disseminated their research results on a variety of consumer applications and networking research topics in poster presentations at MU and externally. They disseminated their results in IEEE/ACM conference/workshop sessions at GI Symposium, NOMS, IUI, BDCAT REU Symposium, BIBM, Blockchain, DSN, AIPR and ICCE.
